title: Integration of Machine-Learned Force Fields for Phonon DOS in Nanoscale Heterostructures
content: The study of emergent phenomena and unique material properties at interfaces, underscored by structural and electronic non-homogeneity, represents a pivotal area of research in materials science, bridging atomic-scale observations with macroscopic behaviors. The investigation into atomic vibrations at interfaces—shaped by structural and chemical discontinuities—sheds light on understanding and engineering phonon-correlated properties, like their role in generating distinctive infrared-optical responses and influencing thermal boundary conductance [1]. In addition to phonon eigenfrequencies, it would be of interest to measure specific atomic eigendisplacements because of their significant roles in understanding phonon wave-like transport [2], especially in the case of chiral phonons, where atoms vibrate circularly around their equilibrium positions [3]. The measurement of phonon eigen-displacements, especially at interfaces, needs ultimate spatial and energy resolutions and remains challenging, typically requiring computational verifications.
